instruction: How did the researchers assess the accuracy of the infrared (IR) models in predicting soil particle-size distribution (PSD) using different methods and soil properties?
Output:
The researchers assessed the accuracy of the infrared (IR) models in predicting soil particle-size distribution (PSD) by scanning a total of 1298 soil samples from eastern Canada using IR technology. They then processed the spectra using Stochastic Gradient Boosting (SGB) to predict the percentages of sand, silt, clay, and carbon in the soil. 

To evaluate the accuracy of the predictions, the researchers compared the results obtained from the IR models to different methods and soil properties. They examined the log-log relationships between settling time and suspension density function (SDF) for different PSD methods, as well as the NIR spectra using either ilr-transformed or raw percentages. 

The researchers also tested the accuracy of NIR predictions using different settling times, such as 0.67 minutes and 2 hours. They compared the accuracy of NIR predictions for sand sieving method and sedimentation method. Additionally, they compared the accuracy of NIR predictions using different gain settings, such as 2X and 4X. 

Furthermore, the researchers compared the accuracy of NIR spectra to MIR spectra.
